learning_outcomes.description: General learning objectives - Subdivide neural systems based on their functional roles and comprehend how these systems interact to produce goal-oriented behaviour.
General learning objectives - Identify structural components of the human brain and relate these to their functional importance, in both in health and disease.
Specific learning objectives - Identify the major subdivisions of the brain, its cellular components and/or support systems.
Specific learning objectives - Explain how sensory information is perceived and transmitted.
Specific learning objectives - Rationalise how motor output is generated and what brain structures are responsible for this expression of behaviour.
Specific learning objectives - Understand the importance of sensory feedback with regards to motor learning and the function of the cerebellum.
Specific learning objectives - Explain how the hypothalamus can sense physiological changes for maintenance of body homeostasis via neuronal and neuro-endocrine communication.
Specific learning objectives - Identify the hippocampus, its associated (limbic) structures, and understand the importance of these brain parts for learning and memory.
Specific learning objectives - Rationalise the importance of the brain's frontal lobe in higher cognitive tasks.
Specific learning objectives - Understand the brain areas and circuits that form the foundation for language and speech.

assessments.due_date:
In-semester Saturday

6/09/2025 - 20/09/2025

Will be held on either the 6/09/25, 13/09/25 or 20/09/25 (personal timetables to be released on 7/08/25).
assessments.task_description:
The in-semester Saturday exam will be held on either 6/09/25, 13/09/25 or 20/09/25.

Students will receive their personal exam timetable from Examinations on or after the Thursday of Week 2. The Deferred In-Semester exam will be scheduled on Saturday, 11/10/25.

The exam will comprise multiple-choice and short answer questions on the material covered in the first 11 lectures.

The exam will be a closed book invigilated exam held on campus, undertaken via the Inspera eAssessment platform. Students will be required to bring a laptop to the exam that meets the device requirements for Inspera. It is important that you check before the exam that your laptop meets the device requirements for using the Inspera Assessment platform. If you do not own a suitable laptop, you can borrow one from the Library . The Library website Get familiar with Inspera provides the latest information for students about using Inspera. Further information about the exam will be provided on Blackboard. 

Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date:
26/09/2025

Note that the exam is scheduled in your regularly scheduled practical group.

Exam duration is approximately 50 minutes.
assessments.task_description:
Students will answer questions concerning pinned specimens of the human brain and/or histology preparations. This closed book exam itself will be approximately 50 minutes in duration, and cover content from pracs 1-5.

You must bring your PPE and present your current student ID card to obtain entry to the examination in the GAF.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

The exam will be a closed book invigilated exam held on campus, undertaken via the Inspera eAssessment platform. It is important that you check before the exam that your laptop meets the device requirements for using the Inspera Assessment platform. If you do not own a suitable laptop, you can borrow one from the Library. The Library website Get familiar with Inspera provides the latest information for students about using Inspera. Further information about the exam will be provided on Blackboard.

Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.topic:
LECTURE 1 & 2: Overview of the Brain - I & II

The first lecture will provide students with a general introduction into the course (Lecture 1). We will then proceed to revise and/or familiarise students with the major subdivisions of the central nervous system, its support structures and terminology (Lecture 2).


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_title: LECTURE 1 & 2: Overview of the Brain - I & II
learning_activities.topic_description: LECTURE 1 & 2: Overview of the Brain - I & II The first lecture will provide students with a general introduction into the course (Lecture 1). We will then proceed to revise and/or familiarise students with the major subdivisions of the central nervous system, its support structures and terminology (Lecture 2).

learning_activities.topic:
Mandatory Gross Anatomy Facility (GAF) induction

During this practical class, students will be introduced to the Gross Anatomy Facility (GAF), specifically in relation to OH&S regulations and the protocols that are to be followed when handling brain specimens. Students will become familiarised with the GAF space.
learning_activities.topic_description: Mandatory Gross Anatomy Facility (GAF) induction During this practical class, students will be introduced to the Gross Anatomy Facility (GAF), specifically in relation to OH&S regulations and the protocols that are to be followed when handling brain specimens. Students will become familiarised with the GAF space.

learning_activities.topic:
LECTURE 3 & 4: Cerebrospinal fluid & blood supply; Sensory Systems I

The first lecture will focus on the maintenance system of the brain: meninges, ventricles, and brain blood supply. The second lecture begins a mini-series into the major (ascending) pathways that relay sensory information from the body and/or external environment to the brain.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_title: LECTURE 3 & 4: Cerebrospinal fluid & blood supply; Sensory Systems I
learning_activities.topic_description: LECTURE 3 & 4: Cerebrospinal fluid & blood supply; Sensory Systems I The first lecture will focus on the maintenance system of the brain: meninges, ventricles, and brain blood supply. The second lecture begins a mini-series into the major (ascending) pathways that relay sensory information from the body and/or external environment to the brain.

learning_activities.topic:
PRACTICAL 1: Meninges, ventricles and blood supply

During this practical class, students will study the blood supply, meningeal coverings, and the ventricular system (which holds the cerebrospinal fluid).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: PRACTICAL 1: Meninges, ventricles and blood supply During this practical class, students will study the blood supply, meningeal coverings, and the ventricular system (which holds the cerebrospinal fluid).

learning_activities.topic:
PRACTICAL 2: Sensory pathways

In this practical, the students will examine brain specimens to identify key structures that are involved in the transmission and processing of sensory information.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: PRACTICAL 2: Sensory pathways In this practical, the students will examine brain specimens to identify key structures that are involved in the transmission and processing of sensory information.

learning_activities.topic:
LECTURE 5 & 6: Sensory Systems II/III

The final two lectures in this mini-series on sensory systems will focus on special senses, in particular vision (first lecture) and hearing (second lecture).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
learning_activities.topic_description: LECTURE 5 & 6: Sensory Systems II/III The final two lectures in this mini-series on sensory systems will focus on special senses, in particular vision (first lecture) and hearing (second lecture).

learning_activities.topic:
PRACTICAL 3: Motor areas and pathways I

Students will examine brain specimens to identify various parts of the brain that are important for motor output.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: PRACTICAL 3: Motor areas and pathways I Students will examine brain specimens to identify various parts of the brain that are important for motor output.

learning_activities.topic:
LECTURES 7 & 8: Motor Systems I & II

These lectures will discuss the pyramidal (first lecture) and extrapyramidal (second lecture) pathways for motor control.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: LECTURES 7 & 8: Motor Systems I & II These lectures will discuss the pyramidal (first lecture) and extrapyramidal (second lecture) pathways for motor control.

learning_activities.topic:
PRACTICAL 4: Motor areas and pathways II

In this practical, students will further examine brain specimens to identify various parts of the brain that are important for motor output.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: PRACTICAL 4: Motor areas and pathways II In this practical, students will further examine brain specimens to identify various parts of the brain that are important for motor output.

learning_activities.topic:
LECTURE 9 & 10: Cranial Nerves; Motor Systems III

The first lecture will discuss in greater detail the origins and function of those cranial nerves that were not yet covered. The second lecture will first focus on the anatomy and function of the basal ganglia.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: LECTURE 9 & 10: Cranial Nerves; Motor Systems III The first lecture will discuss in greater detail the origins and function of those cranial nerves that were not yet covered. The second lecture will first focus on the anatomy and function of the basal ganglia.

learning_activities.topic:
PRACTICAL 5: Hypothalamus and limbic structures

Students will examine the medial surface of the brain, key limbic structures and the autonomic nervous system (ANS).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: PRACTICAL 5: Hypothalamus and limbic structures Students will examine the medial surface of the brain, key limbic structures and the autonomic nervous system (ANS).

learning_activities.topic:
LECTURE 11 & 12: Motor Systems IV; The prefrontal cortex

In the first lecture, we will discuss the anatomy and function of the cerebellum in relation to motor learning. The seconds lecture will review current knowledge on the functional anatomy of the prefrontal cortex. The prefrontal cortex is significantly more developed in humans in comparison to other species. Our view of the functions and neuroanatomy of the prefrontal cortex has substantially changed in the last few decades, from being called the silent cortex to a highly dynamic controller of executive functions, attention and perhaps consciousness.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L06, L09
learning_activities.topic_title: LECTURE 11 & 12: Motor Systems IV; The prefrontal cortex
learning_activities.topic_description: LECTURE 11 & 12: Motor Systems IV; The prefrontal cortex In the first lecture, we will discuss the anatomy and function of the cerebellum in relation to motor learning. The seconds lecture will review current knowledge on the functional anatomy of the prefrontal cortex. The prefrontal cortex is significantly more developed in humans in comparison to other species. Our view of the functions and neuroanatomy of the prefrontal cortex has substantially changed in the last few decades, from being called the silent cortex to a highly dynamic controller of executive functions, attention and perhaps consciousness.

learning_activities.topic:
PRACTICAL 6: Content revision and spotter practice

This practical will feature a broad review of the practical classes to date and have example spotter stations to help with preparation for the mid-semester practical exam.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: PRACTICAL 6: Content revision and spotter practice This practical will feature a broad review of the practical classes to date and have example spotter stations to help with preparation for the mid-semester practical exam.

learning_activities.topic:
LECTURE 13 & 14: Subcortical systems; Integrative Systems I

The first lecture will focus on subcortical systems involved in motivation/reward/addiction (striatum, amygdala, nucleus accumbens, ventral tegmental area). The second lecture will discuss in greater detail the anatomy of the hippocampus, its association/connectivity with limbic structures, and its key role in relation to (spatial) learning and memory.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L08
learning_activities.topic_description: LECTURE 13 & 14: Subcortical systems; Integrative Systems I The first lecture will focus on subcortical systems involved in motivation/reward/addiction (striatum, amygdala, nucleus accumbens, ventral tegmental area). The second lecture will discuss in greater detail the anatomy of the hippocampus, its association/connectivity with limbic structures, and its key role in relation to (spatial) learning and memory.

learning_activities.topic:
PRACTICAL 7: Brain dissection preparation

Students will be introduced into the brain dissection task and associated assessment. Some basic aspects of the dissection will also start on this day.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: PRACTICAL 7: Brain dissection preparation Students will be introduced into the brain dissection task and associated assessment. Some basic aspects of the dissection will also start on this day.

learning_activities.topic:
LECTURE 15 & 16: Integrative Systems II/III

These lectures will discuss the anatomy of the hypothalamus, and its connectivity in relation to sensory, autonomic and limbic circuits, and how these influence behaviour (especially appetite).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L07
learning_activities.topic_description: LECTURE 15 & 16: Integrative Systems II/III These lectures will discuss the anatomy of the hypothalamus, and its connectivity in relation to sensory, autonomic and limbic circuits, and how these influence behaviour (especially appetite).

learning_activities.topic:
In-semester practical exam

Practical Exam
learning_activities.topic_description: In-semester practical exam Practical Exam

learning_activities.topic:
Lecture 17 & 18: The cholinergic forebrain & Alzheimer's disease

This miniseries of two lectures will provide an overview of the anatomy and function of the cholinergic basal forebrain (first lecture), and the neuropathological changes that are observed here and in other brain structures in Alzheimer's disease through neuroimaging and/or post-mortem histopathological examination (second lecture).

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture 17 & 18: The cholinergic forebrain & Alzheimer's disease This miniseries of two lectures will provide an overview of the anatomy and function of the cholinergic basal forebrain (first lecture), and the neuropathological changes that are observed here and in other brain structures in Alzheimer's disease through neuroimaging and/or post-mortem histopathological examination (second lecture).

learning_activities.topic:
PRACTICAL 8: Brain dissection - I

Students will work in groups to continue dissecting a human brain specimen as part of a routine neuropathological examination.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: PRACTICAL 8: Brain dissection - I Students will work in groups to continue dissecting a human brain specimen as part of a routine neuropathological examination.

learning_activities.topic:
LECTURE 19 & 20: Integrative systems IV; Psychiatric disorders

The first lecture will focus on the associative striatum and expand upon the role of striatal subregions in integrating cortical information during decision-making. The second lecture will focus on how these systems are impacted by psychiatric disorders such as drug dependence and schizophrenia.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L05, L08, L09
learning_activities.topic_description: LECTURE 19 & 20: Integrative systems IV; Psychiatric disorders The first lecture will focus on the associative striatum and expand upon the role of striatal subregions in integrating cortical information during decision-making. The second lecture will focus on how these systems are impacted by psychiatric disorders such as drug dependence and schizophrenia.

learning_activities.topic:
PRACTICAL 9: Brain dissection - II

Students will work in groups to continue dissecting a human brain specimen as part of a routine neuropathological examination.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: PRACTICAL 9: Brain dissection - II Students will work in groups to continue dissecting a human brain specimen as part of a routine neuropathological examination.

learning_activities.topic:
LECTURE 21 & 22: Language & Speech I & II

This miniseries of two lectures will provide an up-to-date overview of how modern brain imaging techniques are used to study the comprehension of language and also the production of speech. It will include an in-depth discussion about language problems in those with schizophrenia and its relationship to psychosis.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L04, L05, L09, L10
learning_activities.topic_description: LECTURE 21 & 22:  Language & Speech I & II This miniseries of two lectures will provide an up-to-date overview of how modern brain imaging techniques are used to study the comprehension of language and also the production of speech. It will include an in-depth discussion about language problems in those with schizophrenia and its relationship to psychosis.

learning_activities.topic:
PRACTICAL 10: Brain dissection - III

Students will continue their brain dissection task.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: PRACTICAL 10: Brain dissection - III Students will continue their brain dissection task.

learning_activities.topic:
LECTURE 23 & 24: Clinical imaging and OCD; General discussion

The first lecture will focus on the imaging techniques and clinical manipulations with respect to current obsessive compulsive disorder research and treatment.

A period for general discussion and questions regarding the end of semester exam will follow.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L09
learning_activities.topic_title: LECTURE 23 & 24: Clinical imaging and OCD; General discussion
learning_activities.topic_description: LECTURE 23 & 24:  Clinical imaging and OCD; General discussion The first lecture will focus on the imaging techniques and clinical manipulations with respect to current obsessive compulsive disorder research and treatment. A period for general discussion and questions regarding the end of semester exam will follow.

learning_activities.topic:
PRACTICAL 11: Brain dissection - IV

Students will finalise their brain dissection task

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: PRACTICAL 11: Brain dissection - IV Students will finalise their brain dissection task
